Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I could see the worry etched deep into my partner’s face as I left for work this morning. They barely slept, and I knew they needed me—needed my arms, my words, my steady presence. But the salon was already buzzing when I arrived, and my first client was waiting, her hair thick with product, matted and tangled. She expected me to work my usual magic, to wash away the buildup and leave her hair soft and manageable before I even picked up my scissors. As I massaged shampoo into her scalp, my mind kept drifting home. My partner’s text—“Can you call me on your break?”—flashed on my phone. I felt torn, hands in suds, heart at home. My client chatted about her weekend, oblivious to the storm inside me. I wanted to be the spouse who could drop everything, but I was also the hairdresser who couldn’t rush this process. The tangles wouldn’t wait, and neither would my partner’s pain. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which role needed me more in this moment.
